resources.string: Drink a glass of water first thing in the morning
Get a fitness tracker + track your steps
Switch to non-toxic household cleaning products
Use non-toxic skincare + personal care products
Stand up every 30 minutes while working
Start your day with a healthy morning routine
A teaspoon of apple cider vinegar keeps the doctor away
Use a yoga ball as a desk chair
Intermittent fasting can promote weight loss
Drink a glass of water after every alcoholic beverage
Coffee’s great too, but it’s best to start your day by re-hydrating with a full glass of water. Hydrating first thing in the morning helps to aid digestion, enhance skin health and boost energy.
Taking the stairs instead of the elevator is a simple way to get a little more physical activity in your daily life. It also strengthens and tones your legs and core while you’re at it!
A simple hack for healthy eating (and portion control) is to make half your plate veggies at each meal.
Using a fitness tracker to track your steps is an easy way to make sure you’re getting enough physical activity each day.
Conventional household cleaning products are full of harmful chemical ingredients that are not good for our health (or the health of our kids or pets!).
Similar to cleaning products, conventional skincare and personal care products are formulated with toxic ingredients we should not regularly let absorb into our body’s largest organ.
Maintaining a healthy gut has significant impacts on digestion, skin health, immunity, mental health and more.
Aim to eat real food that’s made of whole food ingredients you would have in your own kitchen pantry, or that your grandmother would recognize.
Reduce the harmful effects of sitting (like at your desk job) by standing up and moving around for a minute or two every half hour.
Vitamin D is one of the most important nutrients for overall health, and sunlight is one of our best sources of it.
Houseplants help to cleanse your indoor air (sadly, it probably needs it!), they’re pretty, and research even shows they improve mood, creativity and problem solving!
Aim to sweat in some way each day—whether that’s via running, biking, dancing, hot yoga, or any other physical activity you enjoy.
Green smoothies as a snack or simple, on-the-go breakfast are an easy way to get your greens in each day.
“The only difference between a good day and a bad day is your attitude.” It’s true—mindset is everything!
Most adults need 7-9 hours of sleep each night. But in addition to quantity, quality of sleep matters too!
Start each day with fulfilling activities that set the tone for how you want to feel—whether that’s inspired, relaxed, productive, or something else.
Aim to eat all the colors of the rainbow each day. (Natural colors only, no Skittles!)
Floss your teeth daily for good dental health and overall health. Not only does flossing daily protect your teeth and gums, but good dental health is also important for immunity and heart health.
Spending regular time alone helps to get to know and stay in touch with yourself (we’re all constantly growing and changing!).
This often gets overlooked as an essential element of healthy living—doing things each day that you enjoy!
There are a gazillion health, environmental and social reasons to choose organic foods.
Apple cider vinegar cures everything (well… almost everything!).
Smiling boosts your physical and mental health (it’s true!), so find ways to smile as often as you can throughout the day.
Fears hold us back and keep us from living life as our best self. Acknowledge your fears and take steps to overcome them.
Save your back/shoulders/neck and strengthen your core by using a yoga ball as a desk chair.
Chronic stress is detrimental to both your physical and mental health.
We’re not really into dieting (restrictions are no fun!), but intermittent fasting is more of an eating pattern than a diet.
Nope, we’re not going to tell you to refrain from alcohol (though you certainly can if you want!).
Practice gratitude each day—this could be when you wake up, before bed, or during your lunch break at work.
